metadata.title: Striking a Balance: A Human Rights Perspective on Informed Consent in Clinical Trials in India
metadata.description: In recent times, India has become a major site for clinical trials. The country’s vast and diverse population provides unique opportunities for medical innovation. While these trials offer possibilities for medical progress, they also raise serious ethical concerns surrounding informed consent, protection of vulnerable populations, transparency, and fair compensation. Informed consent, which ensures that subjects are aware of the risks, benefits, and alternatives before consenting to participate in clinical studies, is an essential aspect of ethical medical research. Yet in India, where socio-economic disparities, cultural norms, and literacy levels vary widely, obtaining truly informed consent presents unique challenges. This article explores how informed consent, when not carefully taken, can become a mere formality rather than a meaningful ethical commitment, especially for vulnerable populations. It argues that informed consent must be deep-rooted in the human rights principles of autonomy and dignity.  In an attempt to achieve an equilibrium between informed consent and human rights principles, this article critically evaluates regulatory frameworks, international ethical guidelines, and judicial developments, highlighting the essence of patient autonomy and the dignity of the research participants, which are vital for the effective conduct of clinical trials. In doing so, the article suggests a rights-based, context-sensitive approach to informed consent that addresses India’s diverse socio-cultural landscape and proposes a reform-oriented consent model.

metadata.title: Admissibility of AI-Generated Forensic Evidence: Legal Standards, Ethical Challenges, and Comparative Jurisprudential Analysis
metadata.description: The implementation of artificial intelligence (AI) into forensic science marks a profound and irreversible transformation, offering unprecedented gains in efficiency, accuracy, and investigative scope. AI applications now span a wide range of disciplines, from biometric identification and DNA analysis to complex crime scene reconstruction and digital evidence authentication. This technological revolution presents significant legal and ethical challenges to judicial systems globally. This report provides a detailed overview of the legal standards governing the admissibility of scientific evidence, focusing on the foundational. It then conducts a deep analysis of the key challenges posed by AI, including the black box problem, insidious algorithmic bias, and the crisis of confidence in digital media authenticity due to generative AI. At Last, the report offers a comparative legal analysis of how different jurisdictions, such as the European Union, the United Kingdom, Canada, and Germany, are addressing these issues through a mix of proactive regulation, evolving common law, and established inquisitorial principles. The report concludes that for AI to serve as a just and reliable tool, its use must be governed by new standards of transparency and accountability, with a continued and central role for human oversight and judgment to protect the fundamental principles of due process and equity.

creators.name: Meghwal, Tapesh
creators.affiliation: Research Scholar, Department of Law, Central University of Karnataka

keywords: Artificial Intelligence (AI), Ethical Challenges, Forensic Evidence, Jurisprudential Analysis, Legal Admissibility, Legal Standards.

metadata.title: AWS Spot Price History
metadata.description:
AWS Spot Price History

This dataset tracks historical prices for AWS spot prices across all regions. It is updated automatically on the 1st of each month to contain data from the previous month.

Data format

Each month of data is stored as a ZStandard-compressed .tsv.zst file.

The data format matches that returned by AWS's describe-spot-instance-prices, with the exception that availability zones have been replaced by their global ID. For instance, here are some example lines from one capture:

euc1-az2        i4i.8xlarge     Linux/UNIX      1.231800        2023-02-28T23:59:57+00:00
euc1-az3        r5b.8xlarge     Red Hat Enterprise Linux        0.749600        2023-02-28T23:59:58+00:00
euc1-az3        r5b.8xlarge     SUSE Linux      0.744600        2023-02-28T23:59:58+00:00
euc1-az3        r5b.8xlarge     Linux/UNIX      0.619600        2023-02-28T23:59:58+00:00
euc1-az3        m5n.4xlarge     Red Hat Enterprise Linux        0.476000        2023-02-28T23:59:59+00:00
euc1-az2        m5n.4xlarge     Red Hat Enterprise Linux        0.492000        2023-02-28T23:59:59+00:00
euc1-az3        m5n.4xlarge     SUSE Linux      0.471000        2023-02-28T23:59:59+00:00
euc1-az2        m5n.4xlarge     SUSE Linux      0.487000        2023-02-28T23:59:59+00:00
euc1-az3        m5n.4xlarge     Linux/UNIX      0.346000        2023-02-28T23:59:59+00:00
euc1-az2        m5n.4xlarge     Linux/UNIX      0.362000        2023-02-28T23:59:59+00:00

When fetching spot instance pricing from AWS, results contain some prices from the previous month so that the price is known at the start of the month. These prices are adjusted in this dataset to be at the exact start of the month UTC:

euw3-az2        g4dn.4xlarge    Linux/UNIX      0.558600        2023-01-01T00:00:00+00:00

For data from 2023-01 and before, this data was fetched more than one month at a time. This should have no negative impact unless, for example, an instance type was retired before the month began (and there should therefore be no price). These older files also only contain default regions. Data from 2023-02 and later contains all regions, including opt-in regions.

Using data

You can process each month individually. If you need the entire data stream at once, you can cat all files to zst together:

cat prices/*/*.tsv.zst | zstd -d

metadata.title: Management of multiple anterior crossbite with Catlan's appliance during early mixed dentition
metadata.description:
Introduction: Anterior crossbite, particularly during the mixed dentition stage, is a frequently encountered malocclusion affecting approximately 4–5% of the pediatric population. When left untreated, it may lead to complications in function, esthetics, and jaw development. Early intervention is essential to guide proper occlusal relationships.

Case History: A 10-year-old patient presented with a chief complaint of reversed bite involving the upper front teeth, specifically teeth 11, 12, 21, and 22. The patient reported decreased self-confidence due to the appearance of the bite. A fixed Catlan’s inclined bite plane appliance had already been placed on the lower anterior teeth, and the patient came in for follow-up and monitoring.

Discussion: Treatment of anterior crossbite can involve various removable or fixed appliances, with inclined bite planes offering the advantage of minimal dependence on patient compliance. Catlan’s appliance, a lower inclined bite plane, facilitates proper overjet and overbite relationships through a simple yet effective mechanism. In this case, its use allowed correction of a four-incisor anterior crossbite efficiently, without damaging dental or periodontal structures.

Conclusion: Early correction of anterior crossbite using Catlan’s appliance can be a reliable, non-invasive, and quick solution, particularly when patient cooperation is limited. This case highlights the importance of timely diagnosis and the choice of an appropriate fixed appliance in supporting esthetic and functional rehabilitation.

metadata.title: Explainable Imaging Optimizer: An Heuristic Approach for Explainable Medical Imaging
metadata.description: With the widespread application of artificial intelligence (AI) in medical image analysis, particularly the increasing prominence of deep learning in disease diagnosis and decision support, the medical community is increasingly demanding the interpretability of AI models. Explainable medical imaging (EMI) aims to enable AI models to not only provide highly accurate predictions but also reveal the underlying rationale for their decisions, enabling doctors and patients to understand the model's logic. Traditional interpretability methods often rely on post-processing or gradient saliency map generation, which suffer from unstable interpretations, poor cross-layer consistency, and an inability to directly guide model optimization. This paper proposes a novel Explainable Imaging Optimizer (EIO) algorithm. Its core concept is to embed interpretability into the model optimization process. By leveraging multi-scale explanation consistency constraints and heuristic explanation sensitivity, the model generates stable and reliable explanation vectors during training and automatically enhances the attention weights for key lesion regions during parameter optimization. This paper provides a detailed explanation of the algorithm design, mathematical formulation, and innovative mechanisms, providing a novel optimization strategy for interpretable medical imaging.

data.title: Explainable Imaging Optimizer: An Heuristic Approach for Explainable Medical Imaging

files.key: Explainable Imaging Optimizer An Heuristic Approach for Explainable Medical Imaging.pdf

links.self: https://zenodo.org/api/records/17498356/files/Explainable Imaging Optimizer An Heuristic Approach for Explainable Medical Imaging.pdf/content

metadata.title: Risk-Aware Dynamic Defense Optimizer: An AI-Driven Approach to Cyber Defense
metadata.description: With the continuous advancement of cyberattack technologies, traditional rule-based defense methods face numerous limitations in responding to complex attacks. Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly being used in security defense, but existing methods often rely on fixed action sets or static defense strategies, lacking dynamic awareness of potential risks and adaptive optimization mechanisms. This paper proposes a Risk-Aware Dynamic Defense Optimizer (RADDO) algorithm that combines multi-level risk quantification, dynamic defense generation, and risk-sensitive gradient optimization to adaptively generate and optimize network defense strategies. The algorithm constructs a node risk vector R_i^t and the overall network risk R_net^t to focus defense on high-risk nodes. It then uses a multidimensional reward function R_total^t to guide defense strategy optimization, thereby improving defense efficiency, reducing resource consumption, and limiting the spread of potential risks. This paper details the algorithm's core mechanisms and mathematical formulations, including risk modeling, dynamic defense generation, reward function definition, and risk-sensitive gradient update methods, highlighting the characteristics and advantages of AI in cybersecurity defense.

data.title: Risk-Aware Dynamic Defense Optimizer: An AI-Driven Approach to Cyber Defense

files.key: Risk-Aware Dynamic Defense Optimizer An AI-Driven Approach to Cyber Defense.pdf

metadata.title: A Theory of Everything
metadata.description: This document presents a comprehensive thesis on a Theory of Everything (ToE) which unifies all fundamental forces and particles within a single theoretical framework. Integrating advanced theoretical concepts from quantum field theory, general relativity, supersymmetry, string theory, and cosmology, this thesis outlines a proposed Lagrangian encompassing known interactions and fields. Key components such as dark matter, dark energy, neutrino masses, and matter-antimatter asymmetry are addressed, alongside critical aspects like anomaly cancellation, renormalization, and vacuum stability. Experimental validations and mathematical consistency analyses are discussed to provide a roadmap for achieving a fully complete ToE.

dates.description: "Unifying the Universe: A Comprehensive Guide to the Theory of Everything"

files.key: A New Unified Theory of Everything -- Baird., Et al.pdf

links.self: https://zenodo.org/api/records/17498122/files/A New Unified Theory of Everything -- Baird., Et al.pdf/content

metadata.title: Metagenomic Agentic Discovery (MAD) Skills with NMDC
metadata.description:
Agents are AI systems that leverage large language models (LLMs) to carry out complex, open-ended tasks on our behalf — from writing code and analyzing datasets to organizing databases, often with remarkable results. However, getting started with agents can seem daunting, and customizing them even more so. In this seminar, I will demystify agentic systems by walking through how they work and how you can start using them for day-to-day tasks. I'll introduce a new paradigm that allows you to teach agents custom "skills," enabling them to adapt to specialized domains and workflows. As a demonstration, I'll show how to use the NMDC's agentic MCP interface to search for genomic data relevant to microbial metal chelator discovery. I'll close with perspectives on how these tools could integrate into the new BER data lakehouse, and the opportunities they present for accelerating scientific discovery.


https://github.com/microbiomedata/nmdc-mcp

data.title: Metagenomic Agentic Discovery (MAD) Skills with NMDC

metadata.title: PowerSystems.jl — A power system data management package for large scale modeling
metadata.description:
PowerSystems v5.0.0

Diff since v4.6.2

Breaking changes

  • Redefinition of many structs and parsing logic
  • New support for interfaces with Supplemental Attributes
  • Changes to the TimeSeries handling
  • Support for New Hydro Structures
  • Support for New HVDC structures.

data.title: PowerSystems.jl — A power system data management package for large scale modeling

metadata.title: AI-Powered MRI Analysis for Early Detection and Staging of Oral Cancer: A Pilot Diagnostic Study
metadata.description: This pilot diagnostic study rigorously evaluates the efficacy of advanced, powered MRI—specifically multiparametric protocols incorporating Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI) and Dynamic Contrast-Enhanced (DCE-MRI) sequences—for the early detection and precise staging of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC). The research demonstrates that quantitative biomarkers derived from these sequences, such as Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC) and pharmacokinetic parameters, provide high diagnostic accuracy in differentiating early-stage (T1/T2) tumors from benign lesions and normal tissue. Furthermore, the findings indicate that this non-invasive approach significantly improves the assessment of key prognostic features, including tumor depth of invasion (DOI), perineural spread, and bone marrow involvement, thereby offering a powerful tool to complement clinical examination and guide subsequent treatment planning for improved patient outcomes.
keywords: Oral cancer; MRI; artificial intelligence; deep learning; 3D ResNet; tumor staging; diagnostic accuracy

data.title: AI-Powered MRI Analysis for Early Detection and Staging of Oral Cancer: A Pilot Diagnostic Study
